author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Takes Stock?
description: Randolph Ross presents a capital puzzle on a celebratory day.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Saturday is the 78th anniversary of the Times puzzle. This is also Randolph Ross’s 25th Saturday grid, on top of his 50 Sunday puzzles since his 1991 debut! Think about it, that’s practically a full year of Sundays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘The Thing About Harry’ and ‘Winn-Dixie’
description: A new romantic comedy debuts on Freeform. And the childhood story of a girl and her dog comes to Disney Plus.
content: THE THING ABOUT HARRY (2020) 8 p.m. on Freeform. Created by the ABC-friendly Peter Paige — who directed “The Fosters” and its spinoff, “Good Trouble” — “The Thing About Harry” is a heartwarming rom-com that debuts just after Valentine’s Day. The movie, which takes place on the holiday itself, details the unraveling of a high school grudge between Sam (Jake Borelli) and Harry (Niko Terho) when they find themselves on a long road trip together. Sam, who has been proudly gay and uniquely himself since high school, has failed to get along with Harry, a former jock. But as the two spend time together, Sam learns that Harry is also gay, opening up the possibility for romance. The cast is supplemented by Netflix stars Britt Baron and Karamo Brown.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 15, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 15, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about Attorney General William P. Barr’s rebuke of President Trump’s attacks on the Justice Department misstated who informed Mr. Trump of what Mr. Barr planned to say in an ABC News interview. The attorney general’s office, not Mr. Barr himself, sent word to a White House official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Maggie Astor
title: The Fallout From New Hampshire: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: There are “only” eight candidates left in the Democratic primary and we still do not know who won Iowa. Here is a recap of what you might have missed from a busy week in the Democratic primary.
content: Well, that was exhausting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
title: William Barr Moves to Take the Reins of Politically Charged Cases
description: Amid mounting furor over politicization at the Justice Department, the attorney general ordered reviews of such investigations and prosecutions.
content: WASHINGTON — While Attorney General William P. Barr asserted his independence from the White House this week, he has also been quietly intervening in a series of politically charged cases, including against Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, people familiar with the matter said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Motoko Rich
title: Couple Tests Positive for Coronavirus After Returning From Vacation in Hawaii
description: The husband and wife, both in their 60s, were confirmed to have the virus after returning home to Japan. Officials in Hawaii were racing to find people they may have met in the state.
content: A married couple tested positive for the coronavirus in Japan this week after returning from a 10-day vacation in Hawaii, during which the man began showing symptoms, health officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Richard Quinn: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Richard Quinn: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Richard Quinn: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Barbara Remington, Illustrator of Tolkien Book Covers, Dies at 90
description: Her work for the 1965 paperback editions of “The Lord of the Rings” and “The Hobbit” achieved mass-cult status. But she hadn’t read the books when she got the job.
content: Barbara Remington, the illustrator who created the most widely recognized covers for J.R.R. Tolkien’s “The Lord of the Rings” trilogy and “The Hobbit” — which she quickly executed before she even had the chance to read the books — died on Jan. 23 in Susquehanna, Pa. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Trump’s Whisper Network
description: What happens when the left cedes the free speech high ground?
content: Several months after the Harvey Weinstein scandal broke and the #MeToo movement got powerfully underway, Katie Roiphe, writing in the reliably liberal Harper’s Magazine, wrote an essay on what she called “The Other Whisper Network.” It was the sort of piece that took great honesty to write and greater courage to publish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: A Meme Girl Mash-Up
description: As the pols take the fight out back to the web, will the dank memes prevail?
content: WASHINGTON — In a meta master stroke, Tina Fey made an epic teen movie, “Mean Girls,” in 2004, then turned it into a Broadway musical and is now making a movie out of the musical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eswar S. Prasad
title: Will the Coronavirus Cause a Recession?
description: The world’s second-largest economy is coming to a near standstill.
content: The rapid spread of the coronavirus is a tough blow for a world economy that seemed on the cusp of a modest revival. The extent of the damage, of course, depends on how soon and how effectively the outbreak is contained. Whatever the trajectory of the epidemic, this is a moment of serious reckoning for China’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Dharisha Bastians
title: U.S. Bars Sri Lankan Army Chief Accused of War Crimes
description: The sanctions are the first international action against Sri Lanka stemming from its brutal civil war. Several members of the new government are also accused of wartime abuses.
content: NEW DELHI — The United States has imposed an entry bar on Sri Lanka’s army chief, Lt. Gen. Shavendra Silva, citing his alleged involvement in war crimes during the final stages of the country’s civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: Damming the Lower Mekong, Devastating the Ways and Means of Life
description: Thailand funded the first dam on the river in Laos, and it is Thai towns, farms and fisheries that are suffering.
content: NONG KHAI, Thailand — The water is so clear on the Mekong River in northeastern Thailand that the sunlight pierces through to the riverbed, transforming the waterway into a glinting, empty aquarium. It is beautiful but it means death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: From Dubai to Mars, With Stops in Colorado and Japan
description: The United Arab Emirates used a novel approach to build the Hope spacecraft, which launches for the red planet this summer.
content: BOULDER, Colo. — In December, a spacecraft named Hope was motionless in the middle of a large clean room on the campus of the University of Colorado, mounted securely on a stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner, Sharon LaFraniere and Nicole Hong
title: Fearful of Trump’s Attacks, Justice Dept. Lawyers Worry Barr Will Leave Them Exposed
description: After a week of tumult, some career prosecutors expressed concerns about political interference and the attorney general’s response to the president weighing in on the prosecution of an associate.
content: WASHINGTON — In an email a few days ago to the 270 lawyers he oversees, Nicola T. Hanna, the United States attorney in Los Angeles, offered a message of reassurance: I am proud of the work you do, he wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: A Presidency Increasingly Guided by Suspicion and Distrust
description: Presidential paranoia is not a new phenomenon but Mr. Trump, burned by impeachment, seems to have elevated it to a governing philosophy of his White House.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump suggested in recent days that he had, in fact, learned a lesson from his now-famous telephone call with Ukraine’s president that ultimately led to his impeachment: Too many people are listening to his phone calls.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Says It Will Evacuate Americans From Cruise Ship
description: Passengers and crew members quarantined off Japan were told by the American Embassy that a chartered flight would arrive on Sunday to take them back to the United States.
content: [This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates on the coronavirus epidemic here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Ryan
title: Packing for Off-Season City Getaways
description: It’s the time for travel deals in cities like Seattle, Boston and Dublin. If you pack smartly, the rain, sleet or “wintry mix” won’t stand a chance.
content: Now that the holidays are over, it’s the time for off-season deals in cities like Seattle, Boston and Dublin. The skies may be gray and the sidewalks slushy, but you’ll face fewer crowds in the museums, find tables at hot restaurants and have a better shot at getting those theater tickets everyone’s talking about. And if you pack smartly — starting with a travel umbrella, of course, and then some or all of the items shown here — the rain, sleet or “wintry mix” won’t stand a chance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: Unmarried, Happily Ever After
description: Being single isn’t a bad thing. In fact, many women prefer it.
content: Despite the increasing number of dating apps, matchmakers, and love advice designed to facilitate romantic connections, many women are opting out of relationships. Instead of moping over singledom or aggressively trying to find partners with arbitrary deadlines in mind, they are declaring to be happily unmarried and proudly find solace in living solo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Do I Have to Pay This Broker Fee or Not?
description: While the real estate industry and the state government argue over a ban on broker fees, prospective renters are left wondering what they’re supposed to do.
content: Q: I am so confused about these new rules banning broker fees for renters now that the rules are on hold. I found a listing on StreetEasy for an $1,850-a-month apartment in Queens. When I texted the broker about it, she said she would not show me the apartment unless I signed a document stating that she was my agent — as opposed to representing the landlord — and that I would pay her a 15 percent fee for renting the apartment. It seems like the broker is trying to protect herself if the rule changes again. Do I have to pay these fees or not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: 31 Reported Dead in Mali, as Attackers Return to Scene of a Massacre
description: The latest attack highlighted the rising ethnic and jihadi violence in West Africa’s vast Sahel region.
content: BAMAKO, Mali — At least 31 people were killed on Friday in an attack on a village that was the scene last year of Mali’s worst civilian massacre in recent memory, the government said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon remind us that getting older beats the alternative.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from a novel called “The Story of a Marriage,” by Andrew Sean Greer, a contemporary writer who won the 2018 Pulitzer Prize for fiction for a book called “Less.” Today’s book (which is not the basis for the 2019 film called “Marriage Story”) takes place in post-World War II San Francisco. It sounds fantastic from its reviews, a story about an unusual marriage that gets disrupted by mysterious revelations, with overtones of race and war throughout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: A Former Owner of Newsweek Pleads Guilty in a Fraud Scheme
description: A Manhattan investigation had led to charges against Etienne Uzac, who co-owned IBT Media, and another media executive.
content: The Manhattan district attorney’s office seized 18 computer servers from the headquarters of Newsweek magazine in Lower Manhattan on Jan. 18, 2018. On Friday, the raid yielded guilty pleas to fraud and money-laundering charges from two publishing executives in Manhattan Criminal Court.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best of London Fashion Week, in Pictures
description: We’ll be updating this post daily with notes on the collections and our favorite images, so remember to check back.
content: The fall 2020 shows are underway in London — and T’s photographers are there to capture it all. We’ll be updating this post daily with notes on the collections and our favorite images, so remember to check back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel J. Wakin
title: Nedda Casei, Mezzo-Soprano Turned Labor Leader, Dies at 87
description: Ms. Casei was an energetic and exciting presence on the Met stage in the 1960s and ’70s before becoming president of a performers’ union.
content: Nedda Casei, who in the 1960s and ’70s could be reliably heard as Suzuki, Maddalena, Lola and other bread-and-butter mezzo-soprano characters at the Metropolitan Opera before transforming herself into a pathbreaking labor leader, died on Jan. 20 in hospice care in Manhattan. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Bloomberg Temptation
description: Will the Democrats try to replace Donald Trump with a power-hungry plutocrat?
content: For a long time the notion of a Michael Bloomberg presidential candidacy seemed like a Manhattan fancy, a conceit with elite appeal but no mass constituency, a fantasy for Acela riders who imagine that the American people are clamoring for a rich person’s idea of centrism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: Bloomberg Is Right About the 2008 Financial Crash
description: It was brought about by a flawed attempt to use credit markets to broaden access to housing.
content: You would have thought that Michael Bloomberg, the former New York City mayor, had picked the right moment to enter the Democratic presidential primaries. From the rural and heavily white states of Iowa and New Hampshire, the contest now moves to South Carolina, where the Democratic electorate is mostly black. A mayor who three times won the trust of one of the world’s most ethnically diverse cities ought to be on solid ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Florida Doctor Bilked $26 Million From Health Insurers, Officials Say
description: Dr. Moses deGraft-Johnson, who told investigators he wanted to one day become president of Ghana, sent nearly $2 million to people or entities there, court records show.
content: A Florida doctor who had ambitions to one day become the president of Ghana faces charges of bilking $26 million from health insurers for surgeries he did not perform or for carrying out unnecessary procedures, federal court records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Luka Doncic Is Good, in Any Language
description: As the 20-year-old Mavericks star makes his N.B.A. All-Star game debut, he’s thinking of the late Kobe Bryant, who once surprised him with trash talk — in Slovenian.
content: CHICAGO — After Luka Doncic of the Dallas Mavericks revealed that Kobe Bryant hit him with some Slovenian trash talk from courtside during a game, admiration for Bryant’s linguistic versatility was a common reaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: NASCAR Races Into an Uncertain Future
description: Stars have retired or are poised to, leaving the sport struggling to get a foothold in the sports landscape.
content: As NASCAR readies for its first, and most important, event of the year, the Daytona 500 on Sunday, it sits at a crossroads. It has hundreds of thousands of passionate and fiercely loyal fans. But the days when it was on the brink of joining the major American sports seem past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Did You Know There Are College Junior Varsity Basketball Teams? North Carolina Has One
description: Most college basketball programs don’t have them anymore, but the Tar Heels and a handful of other universities still keep them around as a pipeline for reserve players.
content: Robbie O’Han was supposed to spend his last year of organized basketball playing mostly against prep schools and junior colleges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Nicholas Kulish
title: Bloomberg’s Billions: How the Candidate Built an Empire of Influence
description: The former mayor’s philanthropy has been a boon for progressive causes, earning support from Democrats nationwide even as parts of his record give them pause.
content: The former mayor’s philanthropy has been a boon for progressive causes, earning support from Democrats nationwide even as parts of his record give them pause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Pete Buttigieg’s Dash for Cash: 10 Fund-Raisers in Two Weeks
description: He leads in the delegate race after Iowa and New Hampshire. But the map is dramatically expanding ahead of Super Tuesday and so are the costs of campaigning.
content: In the compressed and crucial weeks between the New Hampshire primary and Super Tuesday, Pete Buttigieg is moving aggressively to replenish his campaign coffers with an ambitious schedule of 10 fund-raisers held across six states in a 14-day period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger
title: ‘The West Is Winning,’ Pompeo Said. The West Wasn’t Buying It.
description: At a Munich security conference, the president of France urged Europe to create its own policy toward Russia.
content: MUNICH — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo appeared at an annual gathering of Western diplomats and business leaders to declare on Saturday that “the West is winning,’’ something that would be obvious to Trump administration critics, he said, if they were only willing to accept “reality.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: France Confirms First Death in Europe From Coronavirus
description: The death of an 80-year-old Chinese tourist in a Paris hospital was the first known fatality from the new virus outside Asia.
content: LONDON — A Chinese tourist has died in France of the coronavirus, the French health minister said on Saturday, becoming the outbreak’s first fatality in Europe and outside Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Facebook Says Political Candidates Can Use Sponsored Memes
description: Unlike campaign advertisements, the posts are not subject to advance review by Facebook, and the platform does not make money from them.
content: Facebook announced on Friday that it would allow political campaigns and candidates to pay creators for sponsored content on Instagram and Facebook, so long as the posts follow the company’s disclosure guidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Denver Mayor Says Pit Bull Ban Will Stand
description: Mayor Michael B. Hancock said he would veto a measure passed by the City Council that would have repealed the city’s 30-year ban on pit bulls.
content: The mayor of Denver, voicing concern about the “very real risk” of injury to children, said Friday he would veto a measure passed by the City Council that would have repealed the city’s 30-year ban on pit bulls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: Taming the ‘Wild West’ of New York’s Dangerous Private Trash Trucks
description: A sweeping overhaul aims to make commercial garbage pickup safer for pedestrians, workers and the environment.
content: Department of Sanitation trucks collect New Yorkers’ residential trash and recycling, each one covering a compact route. But picking up garbage from businesses is a more chaotic and dangerous process, one that New York City is trying to change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Crunchy, Spicy, Peanut-y Noodles Forever
description: Alison Roman’s wine-braised chicken with artichoke hearts, and Dorie Greenspan’s vanilla marshmallows, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include spicy sesame noodles with chicken and peanuts (above), Alison Roman’s wine-braised chicken with artichoke hearts, and Dorie Greenspan’s vanilla marshmallows. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The President Takes a Campaign Donation From the Pentagon
description: To keep a promise as he runs for re-election, Trump uses more military funds to pay for the border wall.
content: That “big, beautiful wall” President Trump never tires of carrying on about is becoming one of the most expensive campaign stunts ever. It is a potentially unconstitutional one as well, as the Defense Department prepares to divert more billions of dollars authorized by Congress from a variety of weapons programs to generate bragging rights for Mr. Trump’s re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Equality That Wasn’t Enough
description: The most radical Radical Republicans had a better idea of how to cast the 15th Amendment. We should have listened to them.
content: Shortly after acquitting President Trump of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, Senate Republicans moved to confirm two nominees for the federal judiciary. The first, 38-year-old Andrew Brasher, was elevated from a Federal District Court in Alabama to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit. The second, Cory Wilson, is a 49-year-old state appellate judge in Mississippi. He’s being considered for a federal district judgeship in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Brain Injuries Are Common in Battle. The Military Has No Reliable Test for Them.
description: Traumatic brain injury is a signature wound of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. But the military still has no objective way of diagnosing it in the field.
content: U.S. troops at Ayn al Asad Air Base in western Iraq hunkered down in concrete bunkers last month as Iranian missile strikes rocked the runway, destroying guard towers, hangars and buildings used to fly drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: A Scholar of Democracy Gets a 2020 Lab for His Ideas
description: He’s a senior adviser to Elizabeth Warren. He was one of Pete Buttigieg’s groomsmen. For him, the debate between those two rivals on progressivism vs. centrism is personal.
content: WASHINGTON — American democracy has been thoroughly eulogized in recent years, written of with grief and nostalgia in numerous best-selling books. Law professor Ganesh Sitaraman has also taken up the subject, but his has a more aspirational title: “The Great Democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Nationals Beat the Astros. They Still Feel Overshadowed.
description: “It’s disappointing that becomes the talk of the off-season,” Stephen Strasburg said of the Astros and their sign-stealing scandal.
content: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — The clocks in the Washington Nationals’ spring training clubhouse do more than tell time. They are branded with an image of the Commissioner’s Trophy, reminding all who pass through that the Nationals are the reigning World Series champions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Manchester City Vows to Fight, Because Losing Is Unthinkable
description: Suspended from the Champions League for two seasons, a team declares it will clear its name. But City, and European soccer’s governing body, both know the stakes are much bigger than that.
content: MANCHESTER, England — Manchester City needed only a few minutes to come out swinging. It has been that way right from the start, right from the moment Der Spiegel, the German newsmagazine, started publishing the series of exposés that became known as Football Leaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Doping Ruling Knocks Russia off Gold Medal Perch
description: A new doping ruling seems likely to drop Russia into second place for gold medals in the 2014 Olympics in Sochi. Medal counts have long been a point of national pride.
content: MOSCOW — Russia is expected to drop into second place in the gold medal count for the 2014 Winter Olympics after sports officials on Saturday disqualified a biathlon winner for testing positive for a steroid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia P.Q. Wittmeyer
title: I Admire Vegetarians. It’s a Choice I Won’t Ever Make.
description: What seems like a simple decision, to stop eating meat, can alienate us from our traditions.
content: Just before New Year’s, I posted a photo of a giant roast pig on Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Caroline Flack, Who Hosted ‘Love Island,’ Dies by Suicide at 40
description: Ms. Flack, who was a fixture in the British tabloids, began hosting the show in 2015.
content: Caroline Flack, a well-known television personality and former host of ITV’s “Love Island” and other shows in Britain, died on Saturday in London. She was 40.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Matthew Abbott
title: The End of Australia as We Know It
description: What many of us have witnessed this fire season feels alive and monstrous. With climate change forcing a relaxed country to stumble toward new ways of work, leisure and life, will politics follow?
content: SYDNEY, Australia — In a country where there has always been more space than people, where the land and wildlife are cherished like a Picasso, nature is closing in. Fueled by climate change and the world’s refusal to address it, the fires that have burned across Australia are not just destroying lives, or turning forests as large as nations into ashen moonscapes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Motoko Rich and Keith Bradsher
title: Shifting Ground in Coronavirus Fight: U.S. Will Evacuate Americans From Cruise Ship
description: In China, after assurances that people should go back to work, officials partly changed course and announced mandatory quarantine for people returning to Beijing.
content: For much of this past week, as a dangerous viral outbreak continued to rattle the world, officials seemed keen to offer reassurances. Chinese leaders urged people to get back to work. American officials said they saw no need to evacuate citizens from a quarantined cruise ship in Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Paul Mozur
title: To Tame Coronavirus, Mao-Style Social Control Blankets China
description: Despite their high-tech tools, the authorities are mainly relying on a flood of workers to keep hundreds of millions of people from coming in contact with outsiders.
content: SHANGHAI — China has flooded cities and villages with battalions of neighborhood busybodies, uniformed volunteers and Communist Party representatives to carry out one of the biggest social control campaigns in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Former Coach Is Convicted of Lying About Knowledge of Abuse by Larry Nassar
description: Kathie Klages, a former gymnastics coach at Michigan State University, could face up to four years in prison after being found guilty of lying to two investigators.
content: A former Michigan State University gymnastics coach was convicted on Friday of lying to investigators when she told them she did not remember if two teenagers told her that they had been sexually abused by Lawrence G. Nassar, a former team doctor for the university and U.S.A. Gymnastics, who sexually abused numerous girls and young women.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Can ‘Wild West’ of Trash Collection Be Tamed?
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 15, 2020.
content: “Because garbage is an out-of-sight, out-of-mind issue for the majority of us, it’s not hard to then decide to do dirty things with it, no pun intended.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melanie Abrams
title: The Secret to Browns’ Survival
description: The quintessential British boutique is turning 50 at a time when other famous stores are closing their doors.
content: LONDON — New York may increasingly resemble a retail desert, with Barneys in seemingly never-ending liquidation sales and Opening Ceremony closing its stores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Trump Administration Will Raise Tariffs on European Aircraft
description: The Trump administration announced it would increase tariffs on European aircraft in an effort to ramp up pressure in a long-running airplane subsidy dispute.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said it would raise tariffs on European aircraft in an effort to pressure Europe in a long-running trade dispute over airplane subsidies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: Under the Stars with Shiraz and Scorpions
description: They met at the start of a rigorous 10-day tour from the Australian Outback to Melbourne.
content: Simone Rachel Press and Michael Richard Foy met at the end of December 2016 after joining a tour group at a hostel in the remote town of Alice Springs in Australia’s Northern Territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: How Andrew Yang Handled His Asian-American Identity on the Campaign Trail
description: He ran on saving workers from automation, but also leaned into issues of race and representation.
content: Andrew Yang, the Taiwanese-American businessman whose campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination exceeded expectations for a political newcomer, dropped out of the race this week after an eighth-place finish in the New Hampshire primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: A New York Councilman Faces Ethics Charges. For a Third Time.
description: If Andy King is found guilty, the Council speaker said that city lawmakers “should move to expel him.”
content: The last time the City Council had to address Councilman Andy King’s transgressions, it suspended him for 30 days without pay and had a monitor oversee his office in hopes that he would learn a lesson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: An Old and Contested Solution to Boost Reading Scores: Phonics
description: As test scores lag, there’s a growing debate between proponents of the “science of reading,” which emphasizes phonics, and traditional educators who prefer to instill a love of literature.
content: WASHINGTON — “Bit!” Ayana Smith called out as she paced the alphabet rug in front of her kindergarten students at Garrison Elementary School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Ads in Spanish, Obama Cameos: The Democratic Ad Race in Nevada and South Carolina
description: The battle for momentum in the two states could prove pivotal. Here’s how the candidates are making their pitches.
content: In South Carolina, four presidential candidates are running ads featuring praise from former President Barack Obama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: In Marriage, It’s Not About the Dishes. It’s About Respect.
description: Readers share tips for avoiding the pitfalls of gender stereotypes in relationships.
content: “There are powerful historical reasons heterosexual marriages are subject to more tension, miscommunication and resentment than same-sex relationships,” Stephanie Coontz writes in the Op-Ed “How to Make Your Marriage Gayer.” There she explores the findings of a study showing that marriages between gay men appear to be the most equitable, and therefore the happiest, while heterosexual women, who are more often expected to fill stereotypical gender roles, seem to be the least satisfied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: A. E. Hotchner, Writer and Friend of the Famous, Dies at 102
description: His diverse body of work included novels, plays and a memoir about Ernest Hemingway. He was also a partner with his friend Paul Newman in business and charity.
content: A.E. Hotchner, a novelist, playwright, biographer, literary bon vivant and philanthropist whose life was shaped and colored by close friendships with two extraordinarily gifted and well-known men, Ernest Hemingway and Paul Newman, died on Saturday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Give the New Bail Reform Law Time to Work
description: New York lawmakers appear poised to bow to the state’s law enforcement lobby and weaken a law that just took effect.
content: It just so happens that a campaign to roll back New York’s landmark bail reforms is unfolding as Michael Bloomberg’s presidential run forces a reckoning with stop-and-frisk, the policing tactic that led to the harassment and humiliation of millions of innocent people, most of them black and Hispanic boys and men, while Mr. Bloomberg was mayor of New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Developers of Upper West Side Condo Tower May Have to Deconstruct 20 Floors
description: A judge has ordered that the city revoke the building permit for 200 Amsterdam Avenue.
content: In an extraordinary ruling, a State Supreme Court judge has ordered the developers of a nearly completed 668-foot condo tower on the Upper West Side to remove as many as 20 or more floors from the top of the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: ‘I Cannot Remain Silent’
description: A brave voice in China cries out about the regime’s mishandling of the coronavirus.
content: China’s mishandling of the coronavirus outbreak has imperiled itself and the world because it is a land of 21st-century science and 19th-century politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Recline in Your Airplane Seat? A Debate Rages in the Skies and Online
description: You’re either a recliner or you’re not. There appears to be no middle seat here.
content: Put away the blue and black dress — or was it white and gold? And leave behind Yanny or Laurel. Here’s the latest debate to grip the internet: Should you recline in your airplane seat?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Mississippi Governor Declares Emergency Amid Rising Floodwaters
description: Officials urged thousands to evacuate as the Pearl River threatened central Mississippi with the worst flooding in decades.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — Mississippi braced on Saturday for what forecasters warned could be one of the worst floods to hit the central part of the state in decades, prompting officials to urge thousands to leave their homes or otherwise prepare for the rise in water levels expected after nightfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Tessa Majors Killing: 14-Year-Old Boy Charged With Murder
description: The teenager, the second suspect arrested in the case, is believed to have wielded the murder weapon.
content: A 14-year-old boy has been charged with fatally stabbing Tessa Majors, a Barnard College student, during a park robbery near her school in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish and Alexander Burns
title: Bloomberg’s Money Machine: 5 Takeaways on His Political Spending
description: The presidential candidate has donated billions to progressive causes over the years. That has earned him enormous influence with Democrats, even those who take issue with parts of his record.
content: In a divided Democratic field, Michael R. Bloomberg has emerged as a last-minute candidate with an unusual strategy. He is leaning on his record as mayor of New York but also on the good he has done as a philanthropist, betting more than anything that his fortune will enable him to run a national campaign. His campaign is a test of the degree to which a candidate can use his vast wealth to impose himself on the political system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Number Theory
description: Sam Ezersky, how do we solve thee? Comptons les façons.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Sam Ezersky lives puzzles: He’s the associate puzzles editor at The Times and he’s been constructing puzzles for us for nearly one third of his life, since he was 17. This is still just his fourth Sunday (must seem tiny, though, after making the last mega puzzle).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Trip Gabriel
title: Biden Calls on Sanders to Show Accountability for ‘Outrageous’ Online Threats by Followers
description: Joe Biden sharply criticized Bernie Sanders as early voting began before next Saturday’s Nevada Democratic caucuses.
content: LAS VEGAS — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. took aim at Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on Saturday, calling on him to condemn the “vicious, malicious, misogynistic” rhetoric of some Sanders supporters and to do more to stamp it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: China’s Leader, Under Fire, Says He Led Coronavirus Fight Early On
description: Xi Jinping was aware of the outbreak nearly two weeks before he first spoke publicly about it. It could draw him directly into questions about whether officials did too little, too late.
content: Under fire for its response to the coronavirus epidemic, China’s authoritarian government appears to be pushing a new account of events that presents President Xi Jinping as taking early action to fight the outbreak that has convulsed the country.
source.name: The New York Times
